title: 107_s400
content: The Act may be cited as the "Free Trade With Cuba Act". The Congress acknowledges that Cuba is no longer a threat to the United States, and the embargo on trade with Cuba is counterproductive. The United States is using engagement to promote democratic reforms in other countries, and it can support democratic change in Cuba through trade, commerce, travel, and communications. The United States aims to promote democratic change in Cuba through trade, commerce, travel, and communications. The United States aims to promote democratic change in Cuba through trade, commerce, travel, and communications. Section 3 removes provisions restricting trade and other relations with Cuba. The authorities for embargo and sugar quota under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Trading With the Enemy Act with respect to Cuba are repealed. Any export prohibitions under the Export Administration Act of 1979 to Cuba will be removed. The President may impose export controls on Cuba under the Export Administration Act of 1979 and the International Emergency Economic Powers Act in response to a national emergency threat to the United States. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, including related amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing certain paragraphs and sections from various acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing certain paragraphs and sections from various acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. Amendments include removing references to Cuba in section 906(a)(1) and section 908, redesignating paragraphs, and making general changes. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing sections 909, 910, and redesignating section 911 as 909. Additionally, section 211 of the Department of Commerce and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999 is repealed, and the denial of foreign tax credit with respect to Cuba is terminated. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing sections 909, 910, and redesignating section 911 as 909. Section 902(c) of the Food Security Act of 1985 is repealed, and a new flush sentence exempts Cuba from certain provisions after 60 days from enactment. SEC. 4 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 5 pertains to travel. SEC. 5 allows travel to and from Cuba for US citizens without regulation. Transactions related to travel, such as banking activities, are also permitted. The United States Postal Service will establish direct mail service to and from Cuba, using charter providers if necessary. The President is urged to negotiate with the Government of Cuba to settle US nationals' property claims and protect human rights. Effective date is specified. The Act will take effect 60 days after its enactment.
